posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2555738
box? are you looking for a tool box? that doesn't matter so much as the quality of the tools, and you can't beat japanese, see the japanese "engineer" brand tools. snap-on is about equal. they don't overlap in every area, and engineer focuses more on hand tools.
Old tools are great too, they don't make 'em like they used to but for SHTF? Depends on the scenario; surviving in the wilderness? escaping a city? just staying in your home but with no outside help anymore?
I'll tell you the tools I would take with me, from an "everything is gone and I have to move" perspective. I go wild camping a lot and urbexing overnight (aka being homeless in a city temporarily) there's one tool I always want with me;
an axe. it can be both a hammer and cutting tool, makes your firewood, makes your shelter, deters attackers. small 2lb/1kg hatchet is best.
Optional extras:
-those small pocket bolt cutters.
-nibblers (great for sheet metal, snips are good but i prefer nibblers. made a wood burning stove recently from random scrap metal me and my gang of raiders found, pic related, using only snips, a drill, some fireplace cement (can substitute clay/mud) and some wood screws, axe as a hammer was helpful too)
-folding saw (you can get the cheap ones from garden centres)
-pliers and/or adjustable water pump wrench.
-engineer brand side cutters (good for all kinds of things, including trimming nails and minor surgery)
-swiss army knife (explorer) that's the one with the magnifying glass and screwdriver. covers so many bases; can opener, tweezers, blade, even a secret wire stripper function.
Now if you want to get really fancy;
-one good No.2 Phillips screwdriver.
-one good large slotted driver.
-one slotted electricians screwdriver.
(i recommend wera brand screwdrivers)
-set of allen keys
-wood chisel
-brick hammer
-high quality military folding shovel
your pack now weighs about 4kg more. Unless relly necessary, you will probably end up reducing it to swiss army knife and axe.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Fuel oil (red diesel) can be stored for a very long time
and used to heat your home or run a generator

A fireplace is always good to have. Especially one you can use for cooking.

Never return home with an empty gas tank. Keep it at least half filled at all times.
Keep an emergency jerry can at home. Dont forget to use that fuel and replace it with new fuel. Fuel can spoil.

Buy drinking water. Keep it sealed and store it properly.
Buy canned food. Ready to eat meals and some ingredients.
Also store dry food like rice.

Get paper plates, cups etc. Cleaning the dishes when water is scarce is a real pain.
Use plastic cups for drinking water.

>>2556902
You've clearly not been through any or many disasters.

Have a known good supply of clean water you control which means maintain your well if so equipped including backup pump and spare parts or have clean storage like food grade poly barrels you leave empty until warning of disaster (keep full if earthquake country). Rainwater is not a reliable resource but if in a rainy area and a homeowner you can and I do leave rain barrels beneath the edges of building roofs. Mine are for convenient washing after working outdoors and to wet the area where I weld and cut prior to hot work, but they do fine for flushing the shitter and general washing.

Weapons fantasy prep is mostly for retarded larpdreaming incompetents beyond the basic rifle/shotgun/pistol everyone should own anyway. Never plan for your dreams because dreams are stupid. Plan based on reality.

Be extremely handy and able to work on everything you own that matters. That includes at least one simple, common vehicle.

You don't need electricity or entertainment. Reserve food shouls be canned or otherwise stored not to need cold storage. Run genset long enough to use up what you have then shut it down to reserve it for important tasks. Solar battery chargers are enough to run toys, charge LED headlamps (holding a flashlight wastes a hand when wrenching or anything else) etc. LED headlamps remove any need to run lights in your residence. Have small inverters and know how to power and charge what matters. Portable cell towers are easily deployed after major disasters so you want at least one good backup phone. A CB radio or two is useful. Learn why.

This guy's on the right track.
There's not going to be some "SHTF" scenario where the country turns into a giant battle royale. It will be a slow decline, where little by little the standard of living will decrease, and economic security becomes harder to come by.
For some examples, look at what happened in Russia after the Soviet Union dissolved. That was as close as possbile to the "SHTF" the mad max preppers dream of, it was basically the end of the world for many people, and yet life still went on.

What you should be doing is adopting habits that lower your dependency on the immediate economic situation. Growing your own food means that you don't have to worry about going hungry. Learning to repair stuff means that you don't have to go without, and maybe you can repair other people's things in exchange for their talents, like sewing.
Basically the opposite strategy to cowering in your bunker with 2 years of canned beans and 12 guns, shooting anyone who comes near.

No, you're not going to be able to sell any your stocks because the power and the internet no longer work

No, you're not going to be able to use your phone for internet because the cell infrastructure has been rendered non-functional because the towers need power to work.

No, the cash you have on hand is not going to work because everyone is looting Walmart

No, you aren't going to survive the week let alone long enough for the government to regain it's footing since you decided to put all your assets out of physical reach and your fridge only has a few days worth of food and the water no longer works.

No, you can't just drive away since every major road would be packed with cars, crashed or otherwise, and since you thought you could purchase everything when the time came you don't have any long term survival plans or supplies.

And lastly, Katrina was essentially a large, but localized, disaster since no governments or countries were rendered powerless or completely isolated. And people were able to be evacuated. and supplies were able to get in
Evacuations are impossible during an SHTF scenario because their is no where else safe to
run and no help coming.

>>2558379
I'm glad someone mentioned medical supplies. They're cheap when there's no emergency so its a good first step to prepping. Do not buy "medical kits" in the store, they're overpriced garbage and most don't come with useful medical supplies save for a few gauze pads. Assemble your own TRAUMA kit according to your needs. You want things in it to solve problems that require IMMEDIATE medical attention. Some good things to have in it are:

1. Gauze. Lots of Gauze. Various sizes. Do not just get large pads thinking you can cut them to size, cutting gauze is bad for wound healing. ABD tauma pads too.
2. Iodine. It does not expire. Do not use alcohol. Do not use hydrogen peroxide
3. Saline and an insturment to flush wounds with.
4. Tweezers/instruments/flashlight/especially scissors for cutting open clothes to access wounds easier.
5. Steri-strips (butterfly bandages). It really pisses me off how many med kits do not come with these when they really should. These are the best thing to seal up open cut wounds that need to be stitched.
6. Self-adhesive bandage wraps, will come in handy if you can't use a hand.
7. Large triangular bandage for sling
8. Tourniquet. Pray you'll never use it, but having it can be life over death.
9. Eyewash.
10. Your needed emergency meds (Nitroglycerin/epishots)
11. Lighter for sterilizing tools/knives/needles and potential cauterizing.
12. Gloves/safeties/washing kit

Don't get stupid little band aids. Band aids are bullshit, knuckle bandages/square/culture friendly, what the fuck ever they're garbage. You can get stitching stuff, but only use them if you know what the fuck you're doing. It's painful unless you can manage to get anesthetic and needles and you will probably fuck it up worse. Steri-strips are more user friendly and should hold you off until you can get proper treatment.

NEC 200.7(C) Circuits of 50 Volts or More
The use of insulation that is white or gray or that has three continuous white or gray stripes for other than a grounded conductor for circuits of 50 volts or more shall be permitted only as in (1) and (2).
If part of a cable assembly that has the insulation permanently reidentified to indicate its use as an ungrounded conductor by marking tape, painting, or other effective means at its termination and at each location where the conductor is visible and accessible. Identification shall encircle the insulation and shall be a color other than white, gray, or green.

While it does not specify red, the most common colors for hot wires in a residential load center are red and black and there is already a black wire.

>NO WHERE IN THE NEC DOES IT SPECIFIY THAT THE COLOR RED BE USED ON A CURRENT CARRYING CONDUCTOR
It is true that very few colors are specified in the code book. However, choosing a color other than red in that specific application can lead to being gently guided to 90.4 in the code book by the inspector. You'll find out about that once you finish studying the code book just to pass the test. It's a real world thing, not a sneaky code theory question.
Sometimes the AHJ wants purple to be the second phase for a 277/480 system because orange is also a high leg. If you decide to pick blue instead because there is "nothing in the codebook", the AHJ will happily remind you that you, while being technically right, are also wrong. Wrong enough to fail the inspection. Because the authority having jurisdiction for enforcement of theCodehas the responsibility for making interpretations of the rules, for deciding on the approval ofequipment and materials. And how would you, as an electrician, not know to use red.

>I think you only recently introduced RCD's despite them being 20 years old and even then they're on individual points rather than the circuit
this is flat out incorrect, but over here we just call them GFCI rather than RCD.
>solid core ----- they're more prone to breaking,
This isn't true. For one thing, it's a lot easier to break or accidentally nick/cut a strand in a stranded cable during stripping or terminating, which reduced its effective diameter and makes it less than the proper size. Also, IDK how much work hardening you expect to happen with solid core wires in a residential or light commercial setting, but it's simply a non-issue.

Your complaints are simply without merit and are entirely inane and without any relevance. These are non issues, and if you want to complain about USA wiring practices, you should at least pick a topic that is actually worth complaining about like the requirements for buggy AFCI protection, the buggy and insecure "smart" meters, the best effort/rule-of-thumb grounding electrode system rules, etc etc etc.

At the end of the day, the real issue is not hypothetical superiority of one path vs another. The question is: what are the failure rates or safety/damage incidence rates in this system vs another.

a gfci (american term for RCD) outlet can be installed in a way that protects the entire circuit it's installed on just like a gfci/rcd breaker. we use gfci outlets in places where a ground fault is more common (around water sources in homes) so you don't have to go to the breaker box to reset it, and often limit them to just the outlet where ground fault is common to avoid the annoyance of an entire circuit going down from a ground fault at the one outlet
I agree that gfci/rcd breakers are a generally more robust and overall safer solution but we also very commonly use gfci breakers as well

>There should be three conducters and a ground - red and black for the 220, white to the neutral, copper to ground.
You only need a neutral if there is unbalanced current. Any pure 240 VAC device only needs two hots and ground.
>that neutral and ground are the same fucking thing
They are not. Neutrals (grounded conductors) are for unbalanced current return. Grounds (grounding conductors) are for safety. That's why you do not bond neutrals and grounds in subpanels because you could inadvertently energize ground (earth, grounding conductor) in the rest of the system.

>>2551344
Neutral/ground are the same thing for the linemen. Your drop is being held up in the air by your neutral/ground tap to the transformer. The same bare wire that holds your drop up is connected to the center tap, then some grounded mounting hardware, then goes over to your house where it grounds again on your weatherhead.

The ground all up and down the pole is grounded with either a series of ground rods or a coil of wire the pole sits on. Not every pole needs one, it can get its ground from the other poles it's connected to.

Euro anon wants a separate neutral wire to the transformer. Which won't do anything, your 120v appliances will still get 240v through them when the neutral breaks. You'll call the power company and probably get out to avoid the fire.

posts.name: Anonymous

to all the retards who dont know yank electric, listen up. a the equipment grounding conductors and neutrals (grounded conductors) are bonded at the first means of disconnect because in our electrical system, ground fault currents return to the utility on the neutral (grounded conductor). the equipment grounding conductors have nothing to do with bonding or systems grounding. they are 100% necessary as a safety so if there is a ground fault, it has a low resistance path to source which causes a massive current to rush through the breaker, causing it to trip very quickly.
I would highly recommend watching Mike Holt's video on grounding and bonding. it's on youtube, and it's solid gold

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Remove the carpet and pad. If your subfloor is concrete the pad will be glued down, if your subfloor is wood it's probably stapled down. Either way get a razor scraper to either scrape the little bits of glued down pad or knock out the staples. Then you will need to pry out the tackstrip with a prybar.

Vinyl plank is a good option it looks nice and is cheaper than hardwood while also being more scratch resistant. For the most part it can be cut and installed with only a utility knife. Your subfloor needs to be flat so the planks don't have any voids below which can cause the locking mechanism to fail. The typical spec is no more than 3/16" of deviation over a 10ft span but that's often hard to achieve and a lot of contractors don't get anywhere near that flat. You will also need either new baseboards or install 1/4 round or shoe molding on your old ones since the planks require an expansion gap along the perimeter.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2560473
No experience with flooring in particular. I'm 6 years into working in fabrication/fitting so that might have given me an advantage compared to most but unless you're really fucktarded when it comes to working with your hands you'll surely be fine.
Basically in my case it was removing the carpet by ripping it off with pliers and prying off the tack slats, laying foam underlayment over the plywood, put on spacers to the walls, cut boards at random-ish lengths and lay them staggering the joints, bonk them with a piece of wood so the tongue fits nicely into the groove (you're probably gonna need a puller bar for the final side) and put quarter round to hide the spacing gap.

>>2556142
Contrary to what many think, in a combustion engine or turbine, the air and fuel should be as cold as possible, the flame as hot as possible and the exhaust as cold as possible. Carnot cycle PV diagrams will explain this.
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pressure%E2%80%93volume_diagram
So you want to cool the gas as much as possible. You also want to cool the walls of the gas generators if only to prevent it from overheating. gasification takes place around 650 - 800 C which is enough to make metal glow deep red. And that is not user friendly.
The high temperaure heat can power a steam engine/turbine and much of the remaining excess heat can be used to preheat the fuel.

A well tuned gas generator will emit 2 kWh heat for every 1 kWh generated machanical power. Conversion to electricity is close to 100 percent.
Out of that 2 kWh heat you can realistically recover 0.5 - 0.7 kWh as mechanical energy, or 1.1 kWh for a large super high efficiency plant.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2556198
During combustion, things should be as hot as possible, but during the working stroke, you want to turn all that heat into work, which would lower the temperature. In practice, things depend a lot on the geometry.
So for a 4 stroke engine, you want to let the walls cool down from the work being down. Yet for a gas turbine, it is the gas that moved down through the tube, and hot walls are less of a problem, and the working stroke takes place furtehr down the tube.
Years ago, people experiments with ceramic 4 stroke engines that needed no cooling. The idea had potentials but the practical details were too much of a hurdle. Things are different in jet engines, where ceramic hot isostatic pressed (HIP) blades can be used for very high temperatures indeed. Strangely the US has regressed here, and F-35 engines struggle with these issues, while the 60 year old SR-71 hammered across enemy territory at 3+ Mach.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2557074
>Strangely the US has regressed here, and F-35 engines struggle with these issues, while the 60 year old SR-71 hammered across enemy territory at 3+ Mach.
Not really for two reasons. At M 3.2, the SR-71 was operating practically as a ramjet. The turbine air was the bare minimum to keep the hydraulic pressure and electrical supply functioning. Most of the thrust was generated by the bypass air. Second, the F-35 is vastly more fuel efficient at it's intended speeds than the SR-71. The overall pressure ratio is much higher.

>>2556169
>the air and fuel should be as cold as possible
So cold you get misfires?

Except real engines do not operate on a cycle, they are always sucking in new air. The key take away should be a cooler exhaust is better, not a cooler intake, which reduces the rate of combustion and thus efficiency.

>>2556179
He's got a water cooled gasifier that feeds into three woodchip filters at the top, which then feed to an engine, which recirculates some of the exhaust back into the gasifier. The water jackets act as a boiler to power the steam engine. There's also some pre-heating of the intake air with exhaust gases.

>>2558611
>can you compress this and store it in cylinders
Yes, you'd have to filter it or risk plugging the valve on your cylinder. Also, the loss of heat through the cylinder walls would reduce the overall efficiency.

>>2556169
If you were to pressurize the part containing solid fuel it becomes "combustor" in pic related. Compressing cold input air and solid fuel might be worth the trouble: vessels will be smaller, catalysts more active and more importantly: cooling the syngas won't increase efficiency by reducing compressor work. If you're going to take input heat away from the gas turbine, why not take it from higher temperature gas? If you stick with low pressure syngas, the steam turbine might be too small and complicated to bother with: that is you get <1 kW from the steam turbine and 10kW from the gas turbine and you can't run the gas turbine if the steam turbine needs repair.

>>2530328
The secret is that those wood pilings are submerged all the time. Without any oxygen able to get to the wood they last perfectly well for decades.
Other examples are the pilings houses stand on in the Netherlands or those supporting the Speicherstadt in Hamburg Germany.

For wood pilings it is vital that they're submerged all the time. The oxygen starvation prevents or heavily delays the decomposition processes.

Best example is now in the Netherlands those same wood pilings. Due to the heavy dewatering of the low laying areas for pasture the soil itself drops down exposing the pilings themselves at the top causing them to rot right under the brick walls.

There's an old dude on Ambergris Caye who's the last remaining fisherman in the area permitted to harvest live conch from the reefs. Every day he goes out and gets a haul of conch, then putters his boat over to the same spot where he's been cleaning them for decades. He pops them out of their shells, and tosses all the shells overboard, to the point that the spot is a shallow area from the tens of thousands of accumulated conch shells.
He makes middling money from selling the meat to restaurants, but the wild thing is that he could set up a 20 sqft stall in San Pedro and sell these shells to tourists for $50-100 apiece, easily. Could probably make 10x his current income, even accounting for the retail space rent and the cost of hiring someone to staff it full-time, but he just throws the things away. My mom traded him a cold soda for a shell the size of her head.

The only design I've ever liked was one built around a simple lever. The Splitting head was a giant heavy maul, probably a couple hundred pounds, on the end of a boom. On the other side of the lever there was a counterweight, heavy enough to just slightly overpower the maul and raise it up.

>if it's so simple and easy to save that kind of money or generate your own power and never worry about blackouts?
A solar setup and battery backup are most effective at saving money when you have expensive electricity or if blackouts are a meaningful concern where you are. Tons of people in places like California are going solar with backups for exactly this reason (and to be able to save money by using the system to offset their electricity consumption to take advantage of different pricing during off-peak hours)

If short term blackouts are your primary concern, then a generator and a couple cans of gas might be a more effective solution.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2560449
"it depends" because different places have radically different payout schemes with their power company. In my area you cannot receive a payout from the power company; you only get a credit towards your bill, and even that is at a cost recovery rate instead of retail price, and you can only have a maximum of 10kW.

There are other areas where you get paid more than retail rate when you sell power back to the grid, but this type of arrangement has become less and less common over the years as solar has become cheaper and more widespread.

Check with your local power company.
You can also look at calculators online to determine how long it would take your system to pay for itself based on your location, power usage, and local prices of electricity.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Water temperature matters. If you don't have an instant-read thermometer, just boil the water and let it sit for 30 seconds before brewing. If you're doing fiddly coffee stuff you will need a thermometer to get consistent results. Overall, light roasts need hotter water than dark roasts to extract fully.

Coffee grind matters. A lot. Invest in a burr grinder if you want to improve your coffee game. In general, you'll want to grind slightly coarser for dark coffees and slightly finer for lighter coffees.

Freshness matters. Great coffee can be light through dark roast, but old ass coffee is never good. The first and most important step is buying whole beans and not pre-ground stuff, which is usually stale by the time the consumer gets halfway through it.

Water : Beans ratio matters. Different techniques require different ratios.

If you're using filter papers in the process, be sure to check whether you're supposed to rinse them.

And when in doubt, if you don't know something, google the coffee method or question and "James Hoffmann." He's got hundreds of tutorials and has answered basically every question a normal person will ever ask.

French press: 96-98 C water, 60-70 g coffee per L of water. Use a coarser grind than normal. Put some water in the press, add the coffee, swirl it until it foams, add the rest of the water, stir, let steep for 4-6 minutes, plunge, let settle for a minute, pour.

Pour over: 100 C water, 30 g coffee per 500 mL of water. If you're using a Chemex, grind coarser because their filters are thicker. Review online tutorials for techniques, there are many.

Cowboy cup: 100 C water, 65-80 g ground coffee per litre of water. Go as coarse as you'd like. Get a big jug, or better yet just use the kettle, and toss the coffee on top of the water. Let sit for 3 min. Bonk the kettle on the counter, repeat every minute until most of the grounds have settled. For a cleaner cup, sprinkle cold water on the top to help it settle. Good camping skill too.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2551504
>sour vs bitter for OP
It's very easy to confuse which of these you're actually tasting. The more I study this the less I'm convinced the sensations are entirely independent. Bitter taste receptors are complex. The primary way I control these two is to grind finer to remove sourness. Most of my astringent cups have been offensively sour. The FP tolerates grinds that are too fine. There's more silt and it's sub optimal but I prefer at least finer than pourover grind.
The beans also need to be good for any coffee. Buy whole bean and keep it in the freezer until you're ready to grind. If it's not aromatic as a powder, it's not going to magically get that way with water. The rest is just good technique with the press.

posts.com:
>>2552996
This is massively underappreciated.
Good coffee happens between 80C (176F) and 90C (194F).
The cooler end almost universally tastes better, rarely is pushing past 85C actually necessary.
People love to bring some water to a boil in their kettle and then go straight to the French Press or Pour-Over, terrible, don't do this.
Figure out what's right for your setup, with my kettle filled halfway it takes < 2 minutes from the time it shuts off for the water to dip to 85C. (High altitude + mineral content means I get a rolling boil at ~94.5C)

Let your shit cool down for a minute, then make your coffee.
Try again but let it cool for 2 minutes, then make your coffee.
If you've been brewing with water that's just off the boil, you'll notice a big improvement with lower temperatures.

Keurig owners, your water temp is adjustable, usually between 187F (86C) and 192F (89C), run that bitch at the lowest temp and use a refillable K-Cup filled to the brim every time, much better coffee out of otherwise shitty-but-convenient machines.

>>2551475
Yo GOD TIER drink master here. I worked at a tea store for 8 years. We made Tea's / Coffee's frappacino's , Tai tea. All sorts of shit. Now the absolute most powerful way to brew anything..

First you need to start with ultra high quality water. No horse shit tap water. No bottled water from the single use bottles the water quality in those is still shit. Get yourself a 5 gallon Jug of water with a tap on it. You can get it from water stores. You want double reverse Osmosis water. Now what you'll want to do is get your coffee bean. I recommend a good kind like 100% Arabica. Some broke fags prefer Guatamalan which is decent. Now what you need to do is grind it into a powder put it in a tea bag or a diffuser and put your diffuser in your coffee pot. And then put the pot of coffee in the fridge for 48-72 hours. This is called cold brew. And it's potent as fuck. Now once you've got your ultra dank cold brew. Pour it into your cup and dilute that shit with milk and brown sugar add a little bit of cinnamon even add a little bit of chocalate flakes and whipped cream if you want to be extra fancy. And that's how you have a kick ass cup of coffee. It's expensive at first. Buying the water jug will set you back about $50. But if you're a serious coffee drinker it'll be worth it. Once you get into the rythm of it it's really not that hard.
> Super high quality water
> Grind bean put in bag
> Put bag in water and put in fridge
> Lasts about a week before it's advisable to throw it out.

If you want to be extra cheeky about it you can heat your cold brew coffee after the fact in a tea kettle or something.

>>2557816
If you don't want blow a shitton of money on a new espresso setup, local used markets are a crapshoot
desu if I hadn't caught stuff used, Breville is the perfect low-effort option to just get what you want; a basic espresso machine and a smart grinder pro is more than enough to get a fine cup

It's very likely the reason your grinder is spraying out grounds is because the roast is dark. When beans get roasted dark they begin to excrete their oil and it causes a lot of static. You can minimize or totally eliminate this effect by spritzing the tiniest bit of water directly onto the burrs before grinding, like if the hopper on top can detach just take it off, spritz it down into the burrs, then replace it and grind

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2557842
Not OP but I’m in that business. A few of our installations ended up on how it’s made. A production company sends us a layout of their building and tell us eg “10 boxes per minute arrive at point A, we want them on pallets with labels on them at point B, you have all the space marked in red to work with, preferably under $2M” or “we dump 14 tonnes of potatoes at loading point X every hour and need them washed and supplied to cutting machine at point Y”. They put that with a lot details (like 20 pages) into an RFQ and send it to some suppliers.

We get these RFQs, compose installations out of standard modules, ad take into account all the stuff that client forgot to ask (forklift access, walking routes, trash, where the staircases go, etc). Most steps in the process are done by different suppliers, and they usually ask 4-5 suppliers for each part to get the best installation/price.

Automotive, space, pharma etc have more strict planning and more integrated projects, my branch (fmcg) is less strict and we move/chance/add/remove equipment all the time even during installation

the heater in the OP pic is a 4800w unit. it will need a 240V supply to operate. a 1500w heater will be pretty ineffective in a shop your size.

insulation is worthwhile though and helps in the summer as well.

>>2547392
OP, I've looked into this same thing a lot, and basically there are several overall trends. You've got your choice of:
-desert areas where noone gives a fuck, like half of the western USA
-Alaska
-rural areas that are economically underdeveloped and usually at least half an hours drive to the nearest grocery store

In the last category, there's actually a lot of rural areas where they aren't actually free from building codes; it's just that there's no enforcement at all. If you drive around an area and you see people on living on little lots with a decrepit travel trailer hooked up to a power pole and lots of junk vehicles in the yard, or living in a shipping container painted up like the confederate flag --- then you're in the right place. Some schizos will argue that the government is going to fly a lidar drone and instantly know when you build a cabin in an area like this, but the trash dwelling rednecks you see as you drive up and down the highways are like a canary in the coal mine.... If THOSE guys haven't been fucked with, then they're not going to fuck with you for building a cabin on a few acres--- especially if you can't be seen by passing traffic.

There's a bunch of poor counties in Tennessee that have specifically opted out of building codes and are extremely homesteader friendly. There's also a lot of cheap land in Arkansas, Missouri, and Alabama with similar features.

Good luck on your search

in my city, ordinance does no allow:
parking on dirt, or your lawn.
having peeling paint on your house visible from public areas.
grass higher than 4 inches.

derelict vehicles

the code inspector ignored the fact that I had 2 other sheds on the side of my house (code says only one allowed), ignored my neighbors shed which was right up to the wall between us, and another neighbors shed which was also not installed per code.

the code compliance guy all but said that they don't enforce code unless they get a complaint.

when I had electricity installed to the shed I followed the rules and had a permit and an electrical contractor (who did it to code). when the inspector came out he had no idea what he was looking at, was checking a conduit that had nothing to do with the job, balked at the circuit breaker not being the same manufacture as the service box (though within code) did not notice certain things the electrician said he should have failed the inspection on, and gave us the green sticker.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Depends on how independent you can be. Do whatever you want on your land if you aren't in the city. Find land that is not part of any town... For example I have land that has an Address of [town name], AL but I'm not actually IN town. All of my utility providers are county utilities because I'm technically not part of town... That being the case, city code doesn't apply to me. County code doesn't care. State/federal code worries about septic... Which unless you have a shit ton of land, does affect others and is a health concern. In MO, septic is the only statewide code that is enforced. So just about any country land out there is going to be good. Just make sure it's more than 3 acres. The only other concern is electric. Has to be up to code all the way up to the breaker box, or the power company won't hook you up. Not a problem though if you are staying off grid.

Tldr; no on can stop you from "camping" on your land or staying in your "hunting cabin".... It just might be somewhat primitive as a result.

I got sent home early for that and another of my trainers told me I wasn't cut out for this. I brought this up with my boss and he said he was inclined to agree. I asked to move to a different area with different trainers (I was about to go Private Pyle on these mfs) and he obliged. I went three months without scrapping any jobs (still made mistakes like bad pickups and not clearing the handle interrupt offset) but they were all fixable. Anon, it seems that your trainers failed you, imho. Type-A personalities do horribly at teaching, in my experience. You want someone who can make the objectives of your work clear and then show you a pathway to execute confidently; throwing a fit over using the wrong kind of brush on a part is a prime example of nit-picking to destroy your students confidence in what they're doing. When it comes to explaining, there is a point where step-by-step information starts becoming a useless tangent. The things that you called "big incidents" were really rookie mistakes that are to be expected from anyone who's new to manufacturing. When your trainer loaded the wrong file and then told you to execute, it was probably one of those dickhead "training test" moments that guys who suck at training tend to do. Forgetting to tighten a part happens, it shouldn't, but it does. That should've been a learning experience, not one requiring a transfer.
I wouldn't consider this transfer the penalty box, just take it, learn from it, and if you want to go back into CNC later you'll probably be able to pick it up elsewhere without too much trouble, especially if you have certifications in order.

>>2546068
You're likely getting RF into your system. You need to check all your grounds, verify your coax isn't garbage, check all other RF connections, verify you have acceptable SWR on the Tx frequency. Then, possibly deal with the shielding of your amp and even the possibility (likely) of poor filtering with the amp.

posts.com: Hello troutsniffers, I'm looking for a handheld cb. I want one with am/fm and ssb, but I can't find any in production models. Currently looking at president randy 2 (or 3) or the Wouxun KG-S72C. Thoughts?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2546560
Ham radio is different things to different people. For me, it's instant communication for when I'm out and about like on a long hike so I don't have to pull out the cellphone just to call or text. I enable APRS to GPS track in case if there's an accident and people need to locate me. It also doubles as backup since if electrcity is out, I'm not one of those congesting the limited cell service as the towers power down during an outage.

The previous also brings up the concept of using ham as emergency communication. Ham bands will not be as congested if an emergency occurs so the traffic won't be as bad. Some people go into it for this reason as it can be used as a public service. GMRS/FRS is going to be one of those services which will be overwhelmed during an emergency since FRS radios are so plentiful. The issue is that >>2546525 is somewhat right. It is a big circlejerk club at times. But it can be used well in events like in ultramarathon trail races.

Some love to tinker. You yourself said about building your own stuff. One person in the club I'm in does nothing but that. He's built some hf rigs for absolute cheap and scrap parts. He only participates in nets and does signal checks on rigs he builds. Another just loves experimenting with antenna designs.

There's a lot in ham radio a person can do. It's almost an endless hobby of things to do. Ham gives a lot of playing around room to do things if you don't like restrictions like on FRS, GMRS, MURS, and CB.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2552752
>>2552752
>Frequency was just an example, I can say 2.4ghz or 433mhz, it won't really matter.
Unfortunately this is not true. Lumped traditional circuit elements like resistors and capacitors do not behave the typical way we analyze circuits when the signal's wavelength is in the order of the lump element. Moreover, the nearby conductor-insulator geometry has a much larger effect on the performance because the field interacts with those other conductors.

When designing at 2-5ghz+ your final mixed or multiplied full-frequency signals travel along something like Microstrip, Stripline, Waveguide, or Coaxial cable, where the neutral or balanced return conductor is precisely shaped and placed. Regular wires and resistors off the shelf won't work, and wire/housing geometry might add meaningful resistance or capacitance where there is no explicit part in the circuit.

This also means small electromagnetic parts like Circulators can be made for high frequencies but not low frequencies or DC

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2552864
>I would even take a bunch of NRF24L01 modules
Seems to be EoL
>and build an array.
Steerable array?
>Where is the tutorial how to calculate such array?
You can apply general antenna array theory. The ARRL Antenna Handbook has a fair bit of information.
I don't know of any tutorial but the general pronciples are well known. The array will have to be coherent, so you have to feed all clocks from a single source. Just like the Nyquist rule, also spatially you need sufficient density, so the antennas should be just less than half a wavelength apart. The more elements you have in one direction, the narrower the beam will be in that same direction. So a 1 x 30 array will essentially produce a fan, just like on ship radars.

> Emit a pulse

>receive the reflection,

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2553162
>Pulse of sine wave? So it's not continuous but discrete?
There is a lot of freedom to chose here. A discrete brief sine wave pulse is a simple start. A continuous FMCW is also common.

>Reflected wave will be weak as fuck?
Yes, you are now looking at the 1/(r^4), as opposed to the more familiar 1/(r^2).
>How sensitive must receiver be in order to collect some reflected waves from 300 ft distance?
This depends on a huuuge number of parameters, including target size, geometry, material and more.
>Does antenna and external amplifier play crucial role here?
Yes. Larger antennas mean narrower beam, more received signal and more ambient noise rejection. Modulation, signals analysis and more also count. Amateurs routinely reflect signals from the moon ("moon bounce" or EME) 400,000 km from Earth, some have also been able to reflect a signal from Venus.

>>2555759
A diy project radio will cost you effectively more for what you get.
Essentially you will need a bunch of tools to get the thing in to working condition. And oscilloscope and signal generator, vector network analyzer, spectrum analyzer etc.

While you could throw together a schematic from dude trust me sources that will throw out harmonics everywhere for like 2$ anything more advance will cost you in terms of tools and time.

So far I've DIY-ed 4 radios from scratch. Cost me about 700$ in tools. The radios i built cost ~35$. I used to sell them as kits for twice that. Still havent recovered the costs of the equipment.

Opposed to thins, you can get a decent used rig for 200$ or a Chinese toy for under 100$ with all the features you could want. Really down to what you want to do

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2523042
>Let's see what happens.
So after 3 days in a warm place it was still very sour, but the acidity definitely got less offensive/sharp. I let it sit for 3 more days but I didn't leave a sample to compare to so couldn't really tell how it's going anymore. But the overall taste turned out rather meh, like there's something missing. With some sugar added I actually liked the original more, even though it almost gives you a chemical burn in the mouth haha.
Treating it with pectic enzyme helped removing most of the haze but it's still not perfectly clear.
In the meanwhile I also made another batch using different (clarified) juice with zero pectin and way less perceived acidity. The recipe was pretty much the same, there was absolutely no foaming, ended up with FG of 1.006 after 5 days. I didn't wait for bubbling to come to a complete stop, but the jar weight pretty much stabilized so there was little point waiting further. With some bentonite it cleared right away, and the taste is oh so much better, specifically there's very little acidity.
Interesting that unless I did something horribly wrong while measuring it, the two batches have TA pretty close at 5.2 and 4.8 g/L respectively, which I believe is pretty tame. pH is around 3.6 in both cases. So I'm pretty confused why do they taste so different.

Once fermentation has died down you'll need to move it to a secondary fermenter to separate it from the yeast and other sediment

Just finished fermenting a batch of bochet mead using honey from my bees. SG: 1.114 OG: 1020 I couldn't get the ec 1118 yeast to go any dryer than 1.020. I assume it's because the 13% alcohol kills them off? Tastes fine though.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2531384
Not him, my experience says 5 weeks to remove the worst volatile alcohols and make it drinkable, 3 months to really mature it (for almost everything). I drink like half of my stuff at 5 weeks and keep the rest indefinitely (until Christmas or birthday or whatever).

But it’s also (probably more) important to keep it in primary for long enough so that the yeasts will eat most of the less volatile heavy alcohols. Once it stops fermenting, give it 5-7 more days before going to secondary.

Letting it ferment dry helps a lot with clearing (low gravity drops the solids more easily) and you can backsweeten it after. Filtering is kind of difficult using a home set up (without sterile pumps and plate filters etc) and almost never really necessary imo

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2531375
You should get the fruit out after 1 to 1.5 weeks, raspberries can start to decay under absence of oxygen which creates sulfuric compounds which in turn spoils your wine. Just strain it while racking it into a second fermenter. Press the pulp, because the largest amount of your yeast will sit in there and you don't want to lose them. After that, you can only wait until fermentation is done.
Testing for sweetness while fermentation is still going will result in you throwing out your entire batch, because it will only taste of yeast and sourness. (Which is completely normal but might give the wrong impression to someone new to this hobby)
Let it ferment completely dry, until no airlock activity is visible, rack it and let it sit for 2 weeks to let it clear. Then you'll get the first impression of where the flavor of your wine is heading.

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2531406
EC1118 should go to 18% but don't be fooled by the SG of 1.020, honey has some unfermentable sugars, it's really rare to get honey to ferment completely dry, even though you should end up around 1.008 at least. Are you really sure that fermentation is completely done?
Normally you should measure the SG, take note and measure again one week later to see if the gravity dropped further.

Also you have your terminology wrong.
OG (Original Gravity) is your starting point. FG (Final Gravity) is the value you end your fermentation with and with which you bottle your wine. SG (Specific Gravity) is just the "unit" of the gravity.

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2533531
>tastes like crap
Blueberry and cherry is a really difficult combo, I can't really imagine those two working together properly.

I think most people don't really understand that fermentation fundamentally changes the taste of what you put into your fermentation vessel. Cherry wine will never taste like cherry juice and the wine will always taste shallower, that's in the nature of it and the exact reason why so many combine it with mead to give it a proper background or foundation.
Also, I can't stress it enough, buy yourself an acidity testing kit. I bet my arse that your acidity is nowhere near where it should be to allow the flavors to come to shine. For a simple fruit wine without any fancy extras I'd at least go for a 7.5g/l.
And in the end it will help to just let it rest for at least 2 months, it will taste like a whole different drink. But with your combo that's not as easy as it looks. Blueberry wines love aging, after a year they will develop a lovely complexity but you can't do that with cherries. Cherry wine will finish developing after 1-2 months and it won't get better than what you have at that time. After a year the flavor and aroma will start to decay and the cherry wine will slowly start to taste bland and hollow.

https://www.thehomebrewforum.co.uk/threads/how-to-make-turbo-cider.69059/

Turbo cider is very quick and simple. Bear in mind you CAN make it taste nice, but like any cider within the first 6 months it's likely to be pretty shit

tl;dr:
>get apple juice (ideally pressed apple juice but you can use juice from concentrate too)
>get yeast (in theory anything but in practice best to get a cider yeast or some kind of champagne/beer yeast)
>make a strong cup of black tea (to replace the tannin you'd get from the apple skins in normal cider)
>put them all in demijohn with airlock
>some guys put in more sugar (to increase alcohol %) or yeast nutrient but I've never done either
>just leave it for like 2-3 weeks, it should start bubbling due to fermentation
>that's basically it

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2537858
>there are websites that tell me only do primary for maybe 7 days and then siphon
Those websites don't know what kind of brew you're making.
If you have solids in your brew like fruit pieces or pulp, you should rack after 1 - 1.5 weeks to split your brew from the fruit. You need to press the fruit / pulp, because most of your yeast will be contained in them. This step is not to get your brew off your yeast but the get the fruit out of your brew because they can start to decay under absence of oxygen which creates sulfuric components which in turn will spoil your brew.
If you have no solids in your brew, you should rack when airlock activity significantly drops, depending on brew, amount of sugar, type of yeast that can vary between 3 days and 5 weeks and can only be forecast with experience or if your recipe states the timing and your brew behaves like the recipe says.

>>2538571
I have a hard time to find English sources for all the German source material I have.
This is a very very short description of anaerobic decomposition:
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decomposition#Anaerobic_vs_aerobic
If you click on the Anaerobic Decomposition Link in the text, you simply get to the article about Anaerobic Digestion and an explanation how it's used in the industry, which doesn't help us at all.
The German article is a bit longer, I'll post it here if you want to let your browser translate it for you:
>https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/F%C3%A4ulnis

The German article further states which components can be created via anaerobic decomposition:

Organic:
>Propionic Acid (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Propionic_acid)
>Acetic Acid (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Acetic_acid)
>Butyric Acid (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Butyric_acid)
>Ethanol (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethanol)
>Various Amines (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Amine)

Anorganic:
>Ammonia (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ammonia)
>Hydrogen Sulfide (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hydrogen_sulfide)

Furthermore, there is always ethanol present in our brews, with which hydrogen sulfides react with to create Mercaptanes like Ethanethiol and other Thioles.
>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethanethiol
>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thiol

The problem with hydrogen sulfides is that it has a really steep threshold for human perception. Every brew contains hydrogen sulfides, it's a normal byproduct of fermentation and the human nose can't even smell it. But as soon as the threshold of 8-10 μg/L is reached, you'll immediately recognize it as a bad smell of rotten eggs.

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2538625
Additionally I translated the text of this German Wikipedia Article using DeepL:
>https://de.wikipedia.org/wiki/B%C3%B6ckser

>Böckser (also called yeast Böxer or Böchser) is a wine defect. The wine gets (similar to the "corker") a so-called off-tone, so an unpleasant aroma. The smell can be reminiscent of garlic, onions, cooked cabbage or rottenness, especially rotten eggs ("H2S-Böckser"). Sometimes a goat-like odor is spoken of, which is why the name Böckser is derived from "buck".

>Böckser can develop as a result of improper production or incorrect storage and is more common in young wines. The "Böckser" is one of the reduction aromas that occur in the absence of air and is caused by the presence of sulfurous substances in the wine. These are formed by yeasts during fermentation, mainly from sulfur-containing amino acids and from sulfites and sulfates. Excessive sulfurization, residues of pesticides, a fermentation temperature that is too high or incorrect pH values can all contribute.

>In order to avoid the Böckser, it is advisable to remove the lees in good time. In the early stage, a Böckser can still be corrected by adding copper- or silver-containing salts (if necessary also together) to the must in small quantities. In use are:

>Copper citrate (in Austria only approved for large-scale trials)
>Copper sulfate
>Silver chloride (banned in Austria since 2001)

>However, as the young wine matures, the addition of these substances becomes less and less promising.

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2538880
>i ordered some nutrient, is it too late to add?
Yes, nutrients only work in the first 3-4 days of main-fermentation. There has been talk here about a certain manufacturer claiming that their nutrients work wherever in the fermentation process, but I wasn't able to confirm that, since in my area that nutrient costs more than 10 times of the regional product that I regularly use.
Raisins give some nutrients to your brew, so there is no immediate worry. Does your brew smell strongly of sulfur, or just a bit? That might be a strong indicator of missing nutrients and/or missing oxygen (in the beginning of fermentation)
Which honey did you use? Orange blossom honey is notorious for a slow fermentation, depending on the region it might even get stuck and restart on it's own, really temperamental. Since they're your bees you should know which fields and forests your bees frequent.

And yes, you should take out the raisins, 2 weeks is plenty. After that, just be patient and let the brew do its thing.

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2538927
>el cheapo grocery store juice
Check the label for the ingredients and make sure there is no sulfites in the juice.

Why would you think that a carbonated cider has remaining sugar? As long as there is sugar and as long as the alcohol tolerance of the yeast is not reached, the yeast will convert all sugars it finds. If you prime it and open it in the first 2-3 days, then of course you'll have remaining sugars, since the yeast isn't that fast but with each passing day the wine will get dryer until no sugar remains.

The thing with carbonation and sweetness is a strange one. CO2 in combination with H2O creates Carbonic Acid (H2CO3) which is acidic, so carbonated cider should taste less sweet than non-carbonated. But on my tongue, carbonated cider tastes sweeter than non-carbonated cider of the same acidity and sweetness. I don't know if that's a real thing or just some oddity of my tongue.

The plastic ones aren't able to be cleaned the same way that glass ones can and so they can sort of absorb weird flavors over time which carries over from batch to batch. When I'm using the word 'clean' here, I don't mean in the sense of sanitation but rather in the sense of chemical impregnation/absorbtion of the plastic.

The upside of them is that they're cheaper, lighter, and less delicate than the glass ones.

You will also find opinions from antiplazzers who feel that plastic will leach chemicals into your brew. If you wouldn't be afraid to drink water or a soda from a plastic bottle (or from a plastic lined can, in the case of canned beer and soda) then you'll be fine in terms of health risks.

only in the praxis of meadmaking over the years, the JAOM recipe certainly isn't getting significantly more nitrogen from the orange. opponent.
raisins being dried grapes, grapes (and malt) have sufficient nutrients for fermentation to work. please note I say sufficient and not optimal. I happen to add nutrient with each pitch, but I'm also aware that millenia of boozemaking has made do with raisins.
I also happen to know that microbes are very industrious when they can't get their primary nutrition - eg malolactic O. Oenii eating citric when out of malic acid.
bottom line, brewers since prehistory and every prison wine vintner would conclude that the yeast are more capable of assimilating raisin nitrogen than a controlled lab test with a subset of s. cerevisiae would yield.
NOW.. I know this doesn't answer your point the way you wanted to, but raisins work albeit non-optimally. if you don't believe me, try the JAOM and see if you're getting fusels and sulfides.
The truth of brewing is that praxis trumps theory and if you told me that a Warhammer 40k chaos brewing spirit lived in my bucket I'd shrug and say "sure, whatever," and do what millenia of brewers have done.
I'd like to see the ceo of yeast nutrients weigh in though. again, big fan of pitching nutrient, but I bow to the collective experiences of drunkards everywhere.

>>2540327
it isn't great but brewing is very forgiving. the term you often see tossed about is sanitization, but not sterilization. this is because the real goal is to give the yeast a chance to out compete pathogens. yeast put out a lot of things that are toxic to bad germs (alcohol, co2, some acids). there are some non pathogenic bacteria that can give off flavors but even a lot of those can dwindle over time. the yeast are good at cleaning up and fighting off threats, you will likely be fine.
when in doubt trust your nose. if it smells putrid or strongly of acetone, stay away. if your nose says "eh, not great but drinkable," then it is just that. and if your nose says "yum" you are good 2 go.

Since all fruit contain sulfur components like Cysteine or Methionine, there is always enough sulfur for the yeasts and the remaining bacteria in the fruit to start the degrading process.

posts.name: M(e)adman

>>2539990
>I'd like to see the ceo of yeast nutrients weigh in though

I absolutely agree with the aspect of "thousands of years of experience trump scientific analysis".
After all, to this day there is no scientific evidence that bananas help against diarrhea but still they do and thousands of nurses on this planet agree.
The thing is that nature and reality doesn't bend to scientific notation. It's the opposite, scientific notation is nothing more than a language that we use to make sense of perceived nature and reality.
Yeasts can thrive on thousands of different fruit, they live on the skin of thousands of different fruit and as soon as the skin is even just slightly damaged, the yeasts will take over the whole body of the fruit. Mankind knows this to be true with grapes for thousands of years. Raisins are nothing more than dried grapes, which can be hydrated just fine with most of their chemical compounds still intact. So why should raisins suddenly be of no use to yeasts?

This >>2540228 is just the perfect example, I've made hundreds of sugar washes in my life, even ones without yeast nutrients. Water and sugar, nothing more and still the yeast thrived. Yes, they weren't as efficient, yes the ABV was lower than normal BUT it created ethanols without a single trace of nutrients. Nobody on this planet can convince me that raisins can't be used as nutrients by yeast, especially under the aspect that "science" still isn't able to explain why yeasts have two different ways to convert sugar to ethanol and what makes yeasts decide which of the two ways to use.

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2544993
The difference between brewing beer and brewing mead is that with beer brewing you need to create your "honey" beforehand.

You need to mash the malt, since there is no sugar in the grains, only starches and enzymes. By mashing it, you extract the starches and you activate the enzymes which in turn start to metabolize the starches into sugars. What is left is a water-sugar mixture like you have when mixing honey into water.

The easiest way to compare the two is by comparing mead brewing with malt-extract brewing, because they're basically the same. The malt-extract is like your honey, you mix it into your water and add the yeast. All grain beer brewing instead is all about mashing, because by your mashing process, you influence the properties of the "honey". (Metaphorically)

Technically beer brewing is a lot more cost intensive than mead brewing, since you need a lot of special equipment and an energy source like electricity or gas.

Just give a heads-up if you want a more in-depth explanation..

Don't worry about the cyanide in the seeds, as long as the seeds are whole and un-crushed, the cyanide extraction is lower than when eating a whole apple with its seeds.
That's why I always recommend to freeze the fruit in the chest freezer over night and let them thaw the day after. That way they become soft and mushy and instead of crushing them, you can just squash them and they'll release a ton of juice.

To the blackberry and blueberry anon, be aware that fruit wine will never taste like the fruit or the juice before fermentation. Blackberry wine is the most extreme example, it will taste very nice and rich and complex, but it will have a sharp and almost peppery quality to it which might seem weird or offensive to someone who never had blackberry wine before. Blueberries go awesome with honey for a blueberry mead, the flavors go hand in hand.

I have no idea whether this thread is only dedicated to brewing or winemaking but I have started making my own liquors which we call in Poland "nalewka". It has nothing to do with fermentation, you just mix some ingredients with alcohol and the strong booze takes the flavours from the rest. If you have a good recipe then it will be delicious and cheap, if anyone was interested then have some recipes recipes and that's the first one:
cherry-chilli nalewka
1,5kg cherries, they can be frozen but the ripe ones in the season are the best
1,5l 95% alcohol
5 chilli peppers
1,5kg sugar
also you need a jar around 4,5l big
first you take the cherries and peppers and bury them in 700gr sugar and 0,5l of 95% alcohol
when the sugar melts (should take about 3 days) you add the rest of the booze
shake every other day, after a month filter it and pour it into bottles but not all of it, leave 1/4l of the fluid in the jar and add the rest of the sugar
after a week it all should melt, pour all the previously drained fluid into a big pot and add the second liquor (you can even squeeze the cherries now for you won't need them any longer and it's also 200ml more as far as I remember)
it should kick like a horse and still have a really strong taste, you can dilute it with vodka and have more of it, if you did it right then you should have a lot of 60% alcoholic liquor that doesn't taste as if it has alcohol in it at all, the chillis kill its taste, cheap and great
the cherries can be drilled or not, but if you use the ones with seeds then it has to be drained after a month because after 1,5 month it supposedly starts releasing toxins, if there are no seeds then you can basically close the jar and forget about it for a few years

>>2530888
From what I've read risk of infection when you reach active fermenting stage is quite low from air born bacteria. The reason being is your wort is producing enough co2 to positively pressure the vessel which does not allow anything in.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2551314
It’s not really the positive pressure alone. Most bacteria found in people or their houses are either obligate anaerobic and don’t like oxygen (so they die in air) or obligate aerobic and won’t grow in your brew because there is almost no oxygen and a lot of CO2. Then there’s the high osmotic pressure, alcohol content, and byproducts that yeasts make specifically to keep bacteria out.

In the initial stage there is no alcohol, no CO2, and the yeasts are still pretty weak from rehydration, so there’s a much bigger contamination risk. But once the yeast is going there are few microorganisms that will be able to establish themselves in the must.

Lactic acid bacteria, acetobacter and brettanomyces (yeasts) are well known exceptions

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2551311
>extreme banana smell and bad taste

>Acetyl CoA + Isoamyl Alcohol = (Iso)amyl Acetate

Isoamyl Acetate is an ester which especially forms at too high fermentation temperatures and gives off a really strong fake banana smell. If your fermentation temperature was indeed too high, you might also have an higher than normal amount of methanol in your brew. In German Hefeweizen beer that ester is a feature and not a bug, but still it is created in strictly controlled amounts.

>Is the correct approach to take it off the lees and just keep it on a vessel for 2 months? Airlock or just close it?
Taking it off the lees and thereby filling it into another vessel is called racking and yes, that's the next step. Putting it into secondary fermentation for strictly 2 months is bullshit though, you should keep it in secondary as long as it takes to reach your desired final gravity, clarity or flavor. There is no rule of thumb. You should still use an airlock for every step of fermentation.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2558063
Normal rinse then soap then star san. More aggressive chemicals may leave traces and ruin your next brew. If you’re sure it’s a mold and it’s a small vessel, you could try to heat it all through to 80C+ for 30 minutes using water or an oven. Will not kill botulism but will kill common brew infections. Brettanomyces is common and may look like a mold (which often die at 70C) but instead is a yeast that really needs 80+ for extended time. In any case don’t use qacs and if you insist on using bleach solution rinse thoroughly and never ever let it dry out

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2559718
Hey Meadman, I'm making my first ever batch of mead this weekend. Can you shoot me some resources to make sure I nail it on my first batch?
Also, will homemade mead taste anything like the mead I buy at my local liquor store?

posts.name: M(e)adman
posts.com:
>>2559762
I think the video from City Steading Brews does it best in terms of explaining it on a beginners level and keeping a proper pace for someone to follow who is not firm in the processes involved.

Take a peek and see for yourself if you can work with it:

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Y0W7K5yBK-g

How your mead will come out depends on several factors:

>Quality and taste of your honey
>Oxygen in your brew before pitching the yeast
>Yeast nutrients
>Fermentation temperature
>Yeast strain (Yes, bread yeast will work)
>Method of back-sweetening
>Acidity level

The biggest punch you'll get by backsweetening with honey, since fermentation changes the essential taste of whatever you fermented. This means fermented cherries won't taste like cherries, fermented blackberries won't taste like blackberries and of course fermented honey won't taste like honey. So by backsweetening with honey, you'll get some of that honey flavor back.
As for the acidity, for a beginners mead I'd just add a baking-sized packet of citric acid (25g) in a 10 liter batch, so probably half a packet in a gallon batch. You won't hit the optimum but even just a little acidity will boost the overall flavor of the mead.

Use a strong, characteristic honey, something delicate like Mimosa Honey will lose a lot of it's flavor and it takes a really strong process reliability to make proper mead out of it. If you're from the US, you can use orange blossom honey, if you're from central to northern Europe, you can try forest honey. If all else fails, just source a local honey and make sure that it has a strong, honey-typical taste and isn't too faint/delicate.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2559786
>If you're from the US, you can use orange blossom honey,
Anecdotally, orange blossom honey seems to stall easier and ferment slower, all other variables including yeast nutrition and aeration being the same. I've seen others say the same thing.
Clover honey and wildflower honey go quickly and are fairly clean flavors. Buckwheat honey is a good strong flavor and I'm a fan especially when paired with a nice black or pu-ehr tea for tannins.
Not honey, but date syrup makes something skin to a nice red wine, goes through primary like wildfire, but takes a long time to age out.
Picrel, my current brews. The lighter batches are clover, the darker clover or buckwheat + tea. Right now the best tasting is an apricot, wildflower and peppercorn batch.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2560107
No need for new yeast if there is live yeast still floating around in it. They will multiply when they get new sugar. Barrels are often re-used to carry over some of the flavours to the next batch and are said to get better over time, oak chips are like new barrels. Chips are easier to overshoot while barrels have the same surface area every time

>>2560199

RIP Jack Keller

Here are all his wine recipies: https://swguildpa.com/wp-content/uploads/2020/11/Jack-Keller-Complete-Requested-Recipes-Collection.pdf

Check out "WELCH'S FROZEN CONCENTRATE WINE", page 222

You can leave out the acid blend, pectic enzyme and yeast nutrient if you dont have them. It won't be award winning, but you can probably get drunk off of it.


My go-to used to be:

4 gallons of wal-mart brand apple juice
a bag of sugar (5 lbs?)
a satchet of wine yeast

Dissolve the sugar in a gallon of juice on the stove, and mix with the rest of the juice in a 5 gallon water cooler jug. Add the yeast.

Wait 3 weeks or longer, pour back into the jugs the juice came in. Leave the sediment behind. Throw in your fridge, drink cold.

The big issue I see with it is it's selling the very worst thing it can, grain fattened animals that are basically the same as obese.

Breeds like wagyu have gone hard for marbling or intramuscular fat but to such an extreme extent especially when you push enough grain into them to get that prized "white fat" and buttery texture.
Grazed is best, if you can buy beef finished on summer pasture and store it yourself you'll eat better and healthier. the feedlot systems or intensive fatteners are selling builk product raised for size as cheaply as possible.
Breed differences are small compared to what you feed it and how it lives and exercise. I still think the best beef I had was a grass summer hill pastured dairy heifer that wouldn't get in calf so went to the abatoir.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2560293
You'll have the simplest return. F this is the first time using free tax, just read and answer the prompts. It's very easy. It's going to start by asking your personal info. Address/ssn/citizenship blah bla, then the W2 part is just filling in what it asks from each box number. It might prompt you to try upgrading for some audit protection or some bullshit just keep with standard. If you get a return, don't opt for the instant option. Just let it process and go direct deposit. It'll take a couple weeks. You'll do the same for state. It'll probably take you 30 minutes. I used turbo tax for years and thought I was saving by only paying like $35 when I was W2. When I became a subcontractor they charged me over $100. I did it one year and then found free tax USA. Never going back.
Oh yeah, a wise boss I used to work for that I still respect and know told me years ago, when it comes to taxes, the goal is to brake even at the end of the year. Don't expect or plan for a return.
Good luck Anon.

1. Noise reduction is one of the harder things, but it makes a big difference to me, since I no longer want to have the radio or TV on all the time, and I can hear every damn dog and leaf blower in the neighborhood when the weather is nice enough to open the windows.

2. Climate control. Good insulation makes this a lot easier. Heat and cooling that is specific to one room can make that room very comfy. But make sure to have plenty of fresh air as well.

3. Good chair and bed. Sometimes you have to experiment to find a chair that fits your body. I had one that seemed fine but after a few months one of my hips started hurting. I changed chairs and that healed up quickly, and the "bad" chair didn't feel uncomfortable.

>>2553125
the stitches look much more defined!
Also, do you make these from patterns or are they freeform? if you know how to read patterns try this one it's really cute https://www.supergurumi.com/amigurumi-crochet-bear-pattern
also try building the animals with spheres it looks better than a long tube and gets you comfortable with sewing and joining the pieces together
For spheres start with 6 single crochet and increase the stitch count by 6 each round (6, 12, 18, 24, 30..) until you get a good size, do a few more rounds without increases, and then do the same thing in reverse with decreases (and if you want the decreases to leave smaller holes only use the front loops (the ones closer to you))

>>2558395
When you sign up for a phone service you provide an IMEI number which is pretty much your phone’s serial number. It tells them exactly what device you are using. What they don’t know is what software it runs since it’s really on the manufacturer to make sure you don’t boot custom firmware.
They can tell the difference between sharing and usage because your phone reports that. Otherwise there’s no quantifiable difference.
You might be guessing “what if I spoofed it and used a different device that enabled sharing and cloned a different devices IMEI?” or “What if I installed custom firmware that didn’t report data sharing?” These are interesting questions, but ones that lead to illegal activities.
It’s possible to be caught since every wireless device has a radio footprint. Every device transmits data a little differently and if it doesn’t match what’s expected, you’ll raise some red flags.
Of course you may just find a provider that doesn’t give a shit with how you use data.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2558395
I had this problem with T-Mobile a few years ago.

You need to fool your data provider into thinking all your data is coming from a phone and not your computer. Your phone company is inspecting the header metadata (shit that's not data itself in data packets your phone sends to and receives from your nearest cell tower).

Data is not exchanged over the internet in a connection, like old-timey landlines, but in discrete chunks of data around which are wrapped identifying data. We call data about data metadata, and the data plus the metadata is the packet. This identifying data is located in the part of the packet called a header, which is similar in concept to the from and to parts of an postal envelope. Along with telling you where it's coming from and where it's going, it also includes a lot of other info.

One of the pieces of info included is the TTL (Time-To-Live), which is a number. This number is decremented by every node through which that packet passes. When this number reaches zero, the packet is discarded by the next node it encounters. This occurs because if it didn't we'd have lost packets being passed around forever, and the internet congestion would never end.

The TTL for most mobile operating systems is IIRC 64. The TTL for Windows, Linux, Mac, and other non-mobile OSes varies, but is usually greater than 64.

Another piece of data is the user agent string. This is information about the operating system, web browser, and other stuff so whatever website you're using can decide what sort of web page to serve you. Some sites have different web pages if you're on mobile or a desktop/laptop.

There are at least 2 things you need to do:
>1. Set the TTL (Time-To-Live) for your operating system to that of a mobile phone operating system.
>2. Set your user agent string for your web browser to that of a mobile web browser.
>3. Verify that things which are basically web browsers like Steam work, and if not find a workaround to get them working.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2560380
>that type of thing should be commonplace
That type of thing IS commonplace. You just don't normally find it by looking into consumer phone plans.

A lot of the IoT and M2M sim providers have plans that can do what you're asking for. Something like Twilio Supersim lets you have any number of devices get connected or disconnected at any time and you just pay by the byte for the data that you use.
There are other providers that might be more suitable for you, but that was the first one to come to mind.

A lot of other providers let you pay per-data-per-sim which still might be cost effective for you depending on how many different SIMs you're going to need. Something like Verizons M2M plans charge ~75 cents per SIM per month.

>>2555122
For anyone else who is wondering and doesnt want to look it up.

The aforementioned Kobalt 7-1/4" sliding miter saw has a crosscut capacity of 2x8"
So you can cut 8" baseboards with it.
It has a 90deg cut depth of 2", so you arent cutting baseboards vertically with it.

The aforementioned Dewalt 12" miter saw has a crosscut capacity of 2x8"
So you can cut 8" baseboards with it
It has a vertical cut capacity of 6-1/2" so you can cut 6.5" base molding with it

Its always good to have hard specs on things when shopping around.

Also a lot, if not most, standard interior mouldings aren't flat on the back so you can't use the fence to hold them vertically if they are too tall. One solution is putting the finished side against the fence, but then you need to transfer your length mark from the finished side to the back accounting for the length of the bevel, or vice-versa, which can result in inaccuracy. Easier to just lay it flat on the deck, tilt the saw, and cut the original mark.

But what is the proper nomenclature so I don't look like an idiot when looking or searching

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2560313
Where I live, OP image is usually called a live-edge slab. You'll usually be given the dimensions for "organic shapes" like this piece that are corner-to-corner, or widest width and longest length, plus its thickness. You can get live edge planed/dressed or rough cut. Sometimes you can get it stabilized.

Otherwise you'll be buying dimensional lumber (exactly what it sounds like), lumber by board feet (unit of measurement), or sheet goods (veneer, particle boards, etc). Also, overpriced "craft boards" that come in a few different sizes.

Regardless, you're not buying timber, which basically means "logs."

Rough sawn and "rough cut" is lumber that's been cut and put up for sale without processing. Rough cut tends to be better for building walls than for furniture. It's texture is, well, rough, and it's usually cheaper. "Dressed" lumber has been processed further, usually meaning it has been planed, which makes it flat and smooth on all four sides (or, sometimes, not all four sides, so read the label on whatever you're buying). Dressed lumber tends to be better for furniture and exposed surfaces.

Stabilized wood has had something added to it that hardens it significantly and makes warping unlikely. You'll see stabilized blanks for pens, knife handles, etc. It's usually stabilized with resin or a similar chemical. Sometimes a live edge slab will have soft spots, holes, etc, and a furniture maker will stabilize it with epoxy resin. Epoxy can be tricky to work with if you don't do your homework beforehand.

I would suggest googling your area to figure out what wood shops are around, plus give Home Depot's website a read, and digest the nomenclature.

I had that exact bracket hanging from a joist in my basement, the weight of the bag hanging there caused the joist to crack in half along it's length. The bag didn't even get used.

Joists are meant to have a load placed on top that can be supported by all of it's wood fibers. A load pulling from below will separate the wood fibers with time.

>>2556834
Cut the strain relief out and solder the wires. Heat shrink them, then cast them in epoxy to remake the 90°. Add heat shrink on both sides over the entire bundle prior to epoxy to replicate the strain relief.

You can get epoxy putty and just stuff it in the area where that 90° angle is

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>2557250
Crimps are almost always better than soldering, only downsides are the increased diameter of the harness because they take a lot of space.
Soldering looks better and takes half the space but solder mixture oxidize and becomes brittle with time increasing resistance + soldering joints create stress on the strands where copper meets the tin potentially breaking the wires, bad on any device under constant vibration and movement (automotive), good for audio or test equipment that sits all day on the workbench.

It's still garbage. The ring pull tab isn't ancient, it was invented in the 1950s. It was discarded because drunks could swallow the tabs and they could cause cuts when sat or stepped on.

They're separated. See that row of clips the pipe runs through? All separated. PEX doesn't need to be insulated unless it runs through an unconditioned space, the same as copper. posts.name: Anonymous
